My heartfelt thanks to @DOckendenLtd for a forensic report, & most of all to @hergehound5 and all the brave families who fought so hard for the truth to be heard. You shouldn’t have had to relive your grief and give so many of your best years to campaigning. We must do better.
@sajidjavid mentioned a 15 year workforce strategy coming soon, but crucially, we need to know this will be backed by the Treasury with a commitment to fund it.
Finally, the report also highlights the ‘urgent need for a robust and funded maternity-wide workforce plan, starting right now, without delay and continuing over multiple years’.
This is clearly a Treasury blockage, but given the urgent need to guarantee safe care in our maternity units I hope they will think again.

The announcement of an extra £127m for maternity services last week was welcome, but the Govt have delivered roughly one tenth of this by my calculation. The @NHSEngland press release states an extra £50m will go to staffing over 2 years.
On the first page of the report, @DOckendenLtd endorses the select committee’s call for an additional £250-£300m per year to invest in morea midwives and obstetricians.

Important to note there are no recommendations; only ‘immediate and essential actions’. That’s inquiry chair code for ‘don’t you dare let this report gather dust and risk further harm to mums and babies’.

Much to digest & uncomfortable Q.s: how could this have gone on for so long undetected across the tenure of every health sec in modern history? The earliest case was in 1973 & latest 2020. Pretty damningly, the many layers of NHS management & regulation gave ‘false reassurances’.

It’s hard to comprehend the scale of the scandal that Donna Ockenden and her team have uncovered at Shrewsbury and Telford NHS Trust. I never could have imagined the 23 cases initially investigated in 2017 were just the tip of a giant iceberg of avoidable deaths and harm….

If Germany can manage more than 2% of GDP, time to ask whether all Europeans should be matching the US 3.7% of GDP on defence. Now cannot be the right moment for the UK to cut troops, tanks and planes... https://t.co/eRSYViqkzY

Britain has a special responsibility to defend an international order we helped to build but sanctions alone will not be enough - we need to review our military capabilities: my question to @borisjohnson https://t.co/VgDu6QM1l8

But even on a grim day like today we should not lose hope. Authoritarian leaders always underestimate the resolve of democracies. We can be slow to get going but an alliance of countries with a shared belief in freedom will always have an unshakeable resolve.

Finally we cannot look at Russia and China separately. Both are deeply committed to upending the US/UK designed post-45 order. China will look at what happens in Ukraine carefully to gauge what the Western response would be to an invasion of Taiwan.
If there is to be a global alliance of democracies to defend the rule of law, European countries need to show their willingness to step up in our own back yard.

Thirdly and more challengingly Europe surely now needs to match the 3.5% of GDP that the US spends on defence. The UK’s integrated review was a step in the right direction but is now out of date. Surely the UK cannot be cutting the army at a time like this?

But that does not mean we cannot offer military support to the Ukrainians to make this invasion as difficult as possible. Ukraine needs to be a millstone round Putin’s neck not a triumphant step towards the restoration of the USSR.

Secondly an effective military response is crucial. Direct combat between NATO and Russian troops is very risky and would be the first time there has been a military conflict between two UN security council nuclear powers.

That means stopping buying $330m of gas every day from Russia (as the West did even without Nordstream 2) and shutting out Russian money from London. But given that Russia has $600 bn of reserves it will take many years to achieve. We need to be in this for the long term.
Firstly economic sanctions are fine but Putin has already predicted and discounted them. What we do needs to be big enough to prevent the Russian state funding the Russian military.

This means a long term strategy as well as a tactical response. The Cold War lasted 43 years at the end of which democracy prevailed without a shot being fired. How do we make that happen a second time but more quickly?

We need to wake up: Putin wants to recreate the USSR & is ready to face us down as he thinks we won’t risk WW3. The most successful international order in the history of humanity - which has allowed millions to live in freedom & lifted millions out of poverty - is under threat.
How does this morning’s news affect the global order, rule of law and the future of democracies? A thread…

Isn't the real reason for the u-turn on mandating vaccines a chronic staffing crisis in the NHS? My question to @sajidjavid https://t.co/SvAn9bY1BK

Let’s hope this decision is a sign the Govt has finally woken up to the scale of the staffing crisis, and will publish a serious workforce plan with long-term independent forecasts on workforce planning and a plan to train, recruit and retain ASAP.

If workforce shortages are so bad that we have to undermine the Secretary of State’s word with a u-turn, where’s the long-promised workforce plan? Where’s the backlog workforce strategy? Why did the Govt vote down a plan for independent forecasts to help workforce planning?

I do concede the practical arguments about workforce shortages are compelling - some predicted entire maternity units could be put at risk - but the solution is not a u-turn on an important safety matter of principle but finally gripping the workforce crisis once and for all.

Who will now believe the govt next time it tries to do the right thing? What happens if we get a more dangerous variant than omicron? Staff who reluctantly got jabbed to keep their job will feel cheated, & staff who held out will feel vindicated that the Govt can’t be trusted.

So I supported the govt when they announced this. And they won the argument: most NHS leaders say this was right but they needed the gov to take a lead. They worked so hard to deliver it. But having marched people to the top of the hill we now have the worst of all worlds.

I considered the issue carefully, with all the sensitivities involved, but concluded it was non-negotiable that staff working with highly vulnerable people should do everything possible to protect them against asymptomatic disease. If that isn't 'do no harm' what is?
I was intending to introduce mandatory flu vaccinations in my final year as Health Secretary before I was moved to another role.
I understand the practical reasons why we have abandoned mandatory vaccinations but think the U-turn is completely wrong. Here's why…

The NHS faces not just omicron staff absences but permanent and dangerous staffing shortfalls. I didn’t persuade the PM to address this properly today but the year is young and the battle goes on… https://t.co/a7uSO9BJHf
It’s now or never for workforce reform…please @sajidjavid @borisjohnson @RishiSunak seize the moment.

We need short term measures including retention bonuses, overseas recruitment & fixing the pensions tax disincentives. But most of all we need a long term plan to make sure we’re training enough drs& nurses for the future.

They rejected this amendment when I proposed it in the Commons on cost grounds. I agree it does cost more to train additional doctors, but not as much as the outrageous £6 bn we spend annually on locum and agency staff caused by shortages.

The starting point is honesty about the gaps which is why it is VITAL the government backs regular independent reviews of the numbers we should be training as Baroness Cumberlege is proposing in her amendment to the Health and Care Bill supported by former NHS CEO Lord Stevens.
With a 2.1m global shortage of doctors & 15m global shortage of nurses it is time to OVERHAUL NHS and care workforce planning.

But why on earth do we allow both our freedoms and the safety of our care to be put at risk by workforce shortages that are ultimately solveable? Omicron may be exacerbating the crisis but it is not the cause of it - poor workforce planning is. And that can be fixed.

It would be a big mistake to think the NHS & care staffing crisis is ‘temporary.’  Even pre Omicron we had 93k NHS vacancies, with shortages in every major speciality, & 105k care vacancies leading to serious gaps in the safety of care offered to patients
https://t.co/gh4OhKMjyo

More encouragingly London covid admissions appear to have peaked according to @HSJnews. Given London is the epicentre the Government are right to hold their nerve whilst doing everything possible to support the NHS, BUT…

If we continue to leave that process to back-room haggling between Treasury and DH ministers in spending reviews, it will never get the focus it needs - and the crisis will just get worse.

That means most of all overhauling broken workforce planning with an independent system - modeled on something like the OBR - to ensure transparent, public projection are made about the number of clinicians we should be training in every specialty.

But sticking plaster after sticking plaster will no longer cut it. Unless we fix workforce planning in the NHS for the long term, the future will be bleak and the number of face to face GP appointments will go down not up.

…incentives to move here including waiving bureaucracy for people moving from countries with good medical training e.g. Canada/Australia, and reform of pension disincentives which drive people into early retirement.

That means in the short-term a big recruitment drive: incentives to persuade retired GPs who stepped up temporarily during the pandemic to extend their service; relaxation of immigration rules on overseas medics…

The lesson? This is a burnt-out workforce running on empty because of a massive mismatch between supply & demand.  The only thing that will convince them not to continue retiring or opting for part-time hours in droves is a clear plan to end the unsustainable pressure they face.

BUT, as someone who tried & failed to get 5000 more GPs into the system, I don’t think this package will turn the tide. We got 000s more graduates into GP surgeries, but we didn't make progress because experienced GPs were retiring/going part time faster than new trainees arrived

A few thoughts on the government’s GP rescue plan announced today….firstly they are right to address crisis in this sector. Some good ideas including a new NHS covenant modeled on the military and more transparency about performance.

But most of all we need to understand, as we rebuild both systems after their biggest ever challenge, that rather than just do what we have always done more efficiently (and with more money) science and innovation can help us leapfrog the old ways of doing things.

We also need more understanding of the pressure points in the social care system and more latent capacity across both the NHS and care system so that other treatments face less interruption next time.

What are the lessons for next time? We need to avoid groupthink about the kind of virus we may face. Too much of our national response, including during the time I was health secretary, was geared around assumption that the most likely pandemic we would face would be a flu one.

It wasn’t just vaccines: 2/3 of Covid treatments were discovered in the UK (dexamethasone has saved a million lives worldwide). The NHS made sure that all patients in need got ventilator & ICU bed - unlike Lombardy & New York (although big costs in disruption to other treatments)

The Oxford AZ vaccine was based on research commissioned by Chris Whitty’s UK Vaccines Network in 2016 following the ebola epidemic in West Africa - & resulted in the world’s most commonly used vaccine, made available to developing countries with no intellectual property charge.

But set against that were the biggest achievements of the British state in our lifetimes. To pre-buy 400 million doses of vaccine before they had been approved was a spectacularly successful gamble that gave us the best vaccine programme in Europe.

Another major failure was in ignoring the vulnerabilities of the social care system. Germany quarantined hospital discharges & Hong Kong sealed off its care homes early on. We prioritised emptying hospitals without enough thought to the risks in care homes.

That delay meant test & trace only got going when infections were at several thousand a day, vastly higher numbers than the successful East Asia T&T systems had to cope with. So it was doomed to fail, & we ended up with 3 lockdowns. Just as across Eur & N.America, many more died.

Had we been humble enough to learn from the approach being taken in places like Taiwan and South Korea, with their experience of SARS and MERS, we could perhaps have avoided lockdowns altogether in the first year.

We conclude that our national response was a curate’s egg of disastrous mistakes and extraordinary genius. The first lockdown was too late & based on flawed scientific advice which should have been challenged earlier.

But in politics it’s important to give credit where it’s due: this is a difficult & painful decision but the right one for families who rely on the NHS/care system & frontline staff who’ve given their all during the pandemic. Bravo to the PM & team for facing up to this challenge

Lots of detail to pick through, & lessons from the last 25 years about increases in funding being wasted. As we tackle the backlog we can’t allow a targets culture to take root because that led unintentionally to Mid Staffs: safety & quality of care matter as much as quantity.

Most of all there is justice for many families forced to sell their house because of a family member gets dementia: when these changes kick in, they will be able to focus their energy on supporting a loved one rather than worrying about money.
Local authorities may ultimately need more than offered today (especially in the short term) but a £ multi-billion rise in their funding will be greatly welcomed.

Today also a big step forward in protecting families from catastrophic care costs. The arguments for/against are well rehearsed but Dilnot’s cap is the only system that has ever come close to consensus.

If you live in US, Ger or Switz your health insurance premiums will go up just as surely as taxes will go up in taxpayer-funded systems. And for all its challenges, our system delivers not equity & value for money, including the lowest medicine prices paid anywhere in the world.

For a Con govt, raising taxes is always a last resort. We know public services are not just about funding, but standards too. But no govt that wants decent healthcare can ignore demographic reality, so today's changes will command support despite general unpopularity of tax rises

Why it is time to scrap the 10-day isolation requirement for those pinged and if we need Covid passports for nightclubs at the end of September, why don't we need them now?  My questions to @nadhimzahawi https://t.co/YA9hNDDFv7

So a Health & Care Premium is the most honest solution, with a sensible debate on whether we’ll fund the new dementia drugs on the way, make our cancer survival rates as good as Denmark/Australia - & proper social care - & how much that’s about funding v.s innnovation/efficiency.

This does not make us 'higher taxed' except in the most literal sense - and ignores the fact that overall costs are often lower in tax based systems because of lower admin costs caused by not having to invoice every individual treatment. https://t.co/LSGFu8txuh

But in the US you pay much more than 8% of income in health insurance. In the future we’re all going to pay more for health due to living longer & new treatments. In the US/Germany/Switzerland/Holland that’s through higher insurance premiums; in systems like ours it’s through tax

Will this turn us into a high tax country? As a Conservative I believe a lightly-taxed economy is essential to our future. But look at this table from the IFS [https://t.co/3iynl3qeQX ]. It shows the US takes 25% in tax v.s 33% in the UK (and higher in most of the rest of Europe]

So the attraction of a Health and Social Care levy is it would fund the NHS backlog in the short term and desperately needed improvements in the social care system in the medium/longer term. It would also be transparent about the need for resources and capacity in both sectors.

The NHS Covid backlog is now the most serious for two decades. As @HSJEditor says we are seeing thousands of people waiting TWO YEARS for surgery for the first time in two decades. That is going to require a big short term increase in capacity: https://t.co/CX8WaR33aI

Then there is a new levy, perhaps set at around 1% of income. This could raise £6 bn+ immediately, actually more than the social care system needs or could cope with right away. But there is somewhere that does need that funding right away...

Another option is to remove exemption for pensioners to pay NI. Logical as they’re the biggest winners from more ££ - but only raises £0.5 bn a year, & also breaches a manifesto promise. After Philip Hammond's attempted changes to NI this would be 'brave', in Sir Humphrey’s words

One option is uncapping the council tax social care precept. Currently capped at 2% annual rise, it’s been less unpopular than feared (I hardly recall any constituency letters & colleagues generally agree). But soaring council tax bills to pay for soc care would change that.

As Chx, Philip Hammond managed to fund the £20 bn rise in the NHS annual budget, which I negotiated with him in 2018, without raising taxes. But given post-pandemic public finances £7+ bn is is likely to be too much for any Chancellor to find down the back of a Treasury sofa.

Let's take as starting point the HSC report which said the sector needs min £7 bn annual raise in its budget over 4-5 years. This covers a cap, demographic changes and increases in the national living wage but not a big expansion of quality or eligibility https://t.co/isSxcdtBCK

It’s progress that the soc care debate has moved on from 'whether' to 'how.' This isn’t just because it wld breach the PM's words on the steps of Downing Street, but a growing realisation that with the Covid backlog we’ll never get the NHS back on its feet without soc care reform

Today's @thetimes headline is wrong: the joint select cttee report into lessons learned from Covid has not been written, let alone seen by any committee mbr. To say that some of the most serious @Dominic2306 allegations have not been substantiated at this stage is quite different

The public inquiry will have the last word, but realistically it will take at least two years to report. I hope our joint recommendations will give the govt some ideas to implement much earlier than that. Watch this space….
...and much earlier transparency on the scientific advice being given to ministers is the other, so we allow more peer-review and quicker course correction.

Our joint report will set out key lessons to be learned and I won't pre-empt. But for me two early lessons stand out: being as nimble, searching and pragmatic in our pandemic response as we were in our vaccine response is one...

Set against this must be our national vaccine triumph: not just securing 400m doses before we knew they’d work, but a flawless NHS roll. So the paradox is that the biggest failures in the performance of the state have to be balanced against some of its most stunning achievements.

I also think (I was part of this groupthink) that we were over-focused on testing targets (100k, then 500k, then 1m/day) so didn't focus on the one metric that matters in a pandemic: proportion of potentially infectious isolating. At times 20-40% of those meant to isolate weren't

This delay meant infections were > 2000 cases/day by the time T&T got going, much higher than in Asia, which set it up to fail, alongside central rather than local contact tracing (which has now been sensibly reversed) and not offering a blanket salary replacement guarantee.

Given that most East Asian countries had fewer lockdowns (in Korea's case no lockdowns) this was a serious failing in our structures, perhaps caused by a 'pandemic flu' mindset although to the credit of our scientists this did not extend to vaccine R & D.

It’s clear ministers were offered two extreme options - suppression (lockdowns) or mitigation (let the virus spread but protect the vulnerable). The East Asian way (close borders, hi tech test & trace) was not modeled by SAGE until April when we were well into lockdown.

Time for a radical overhaul of NHS and care workforce planning: my question to @MattHancock today https://t.co/tlJqYDV4br

This would not solve all the issues around burnout but at least we could look stressed frontline professionals in the eye and say there is a long term solution in place to deal with the chronic excessive workload they face - which has to be the right first step to take.
Would it be expensive? No: the irony is it would be cheaper because we would save money on the annual £6 bn (yes you heard it right) we spend on locum doctors/agency nurses even outside pandemics.

This is supported by the Royal Colleges:  
https://t.co/MKqaHVJVF9 and by the health thinktanks where @AnitaCTHF has even suggested an amendment to the new NHS Bill which would deliver it.
https://t.co/IdwnN4NqR7

We need an independent body - perhaps HEE - to publish independent workforce projections for the next 5/10/20 years based on changes in tech, medicine & skills with recommendations as to the number that should be entering training. More in our report here:
https://t.co/ie1X5wyS8B

We need to look at other reforms that have successfully created a discipline on governments to be more long term - one of the best of which is the way the OBR keeps Chancellors 'honest' about economic projections in budgets.

It takes 7 years to train a doctor and 3 years to train a nurse, so there is never any political incentive to prioritise the training budget. Money will always - and understandably - go first to more pressing short term priorities. Post pandemic we will have quite a few of those.

I set up 5 new medical schools and increased doc/nurse/midwife training places by 25%, one of the biggest ever rises. But I have concluded the system we have now will never deliver the staff we need. Without reform, we will not tackle burnout - & ultimately put patients at risk.

There are shortages in nearly every medical specialty with the number of doctors and nurses we train only indirectly linked to patient numbers or demand, and mainly the result of spending review haggling between the Treasury and DHSC Ministers.

The WHO defines burnout as much more than 'a stressful day at work’: it’s chronic fatigue, emotional exhaustion and a feeling of being distant from your job. The NHS has done much on burnout recently (h/t @Prerana_Issar) but one thing remains: a failed workforce planning system.

However the immediate dividend from his leadership has been the superb NHS response to the pandemic: every patient that needed a ventilator or ICU bed got one and we have rolled out the best vaccination programme in Europe. He should feel extremely proud today.

The progress that will now be made changing the primary model of care towards integrated care will not become clear for a while, not least because it depends on new legislation we expect shortly - but it will none the less be enormous.

But his skills as an operator should not be allowed to conceal his deeply-held passion and support for everything the NHS stands for. He will be remembered for giving the world's 5th largest organisation strategic direction at a time of great challenge.

Simon is a formidable operator, taking more trouble to be briefed on key facts ahead of meetings with ministers or the PM than anyone else I met. He has the rare quality of being able to stay silent in meetings unless he has something important to say, a rare quality in Whitehall

We had a symbiotic relationship: he gave the NHS confidence they had one of their own at the top and I made sure its voice was heard loud and clear in government circles. That partnership ultimately meant a successful negotiation for a 10 year plan & £20 bn budget uplift in 2018

Despite his time as a special adviser in No 10 and in the private sector in the US, SImon has always been NHS to his core. But neither he nor I knew just how bumpy things would become with immense operational and financial pressures across the NHS and social care system.

When we recruited for a successor to Sir David Nicholson in 2013, there was a good deal of trepidation about the role following controversy over the 2012 Act. Simon, however, was the standout candidate and hiring him remains one of the best decisions I have ever taken.

But the biggest unknown was the extent of airborne rather than surface infections. Future guidelines need more focus on ventilation than hands & surfaces. Upgrading ventilation systems - esp in old hospitals - is expensive, but clearly worth doing to prepare for future pandemics.

Speed of testing in hospitals is also a vital tool we should have used earlier: why did it take until November to introduce weekly testing of NHS staff?
https://t.co/dGIrH3MOaC

We should definitely have earlier advice to adhere to social distancing in the non-Covid areas of hospitals. This select committee exchange with Prof Steve Powis demonstrates why crucial time was lost in the early stages: https://t.co/2zsI8EbZfG

So what should the lesson be? Given the CQC has looked at some hospitals who have had multiple hospital acquired outbreaks and found infection controls were good it makes you think that these weren’t the right controls.

Why does this matter? Apart from the human tragedy of so many avoidable deaths, the SAGE paper noted “without any nosocomial transmission the duration of the first wave in hospitals may have been shortened.”
This is not just an England issue. In Scotland at the end of January there were 4055 hospital acquired cases which made up around 21% of COVID hospital patients: https://t.co/b6H9QafE8v

Upper estimates of this data suggest that around 36,000 cases in the first wave were caught this way which could mean 8,000 deaths related to hospital acquired COVID occurred in that wave: https://t.co/vd6QTivDC8
It was even worse: a paper by PHE and LSHTM for SAGE in January stated that 20-25% of infections in hospital patients in the first wave were hospital acquired: https://t.co/bb2yTUTIZM

Hospital acquired COVID-19 remains a major problem as it STILL accounts for 15% of COVID hospital patients: https://t.co/Iy22oDwon9 It remains the biggest undiscussed problem in the pandemic to date: a thread.

We may not need to continue lockdown until cases fall to such a level and I am not advocating as such. But we do need to keep sensible restrictions in place until enhanced contact tracing can be brought in for all new cases.

So it seems a sensible approach to learn from. I asked @didoharding the precise level of cases at which enhanced contact tracing becomes possible & she was unsure. But conditions here are different to Korea so case rate at which this becomes possible is unlikely to be the same.

Korea has kept case transmission below 1,200/day (and is currently around 400/day) so is an example of the kind of relatively low level that makes such detailed contact tracing possible. Even without a vaccine they have not needed a national lockdown.

This is a big step up from the contact tracing we do & much closer to what happens in South Korea & Japan. But impossible with current high levels of transmission. Hence the critical importance of getting case levels down well below the current c 20k/day before ending lockdown.

When such variants arrive, our best strategy - if we want to avoid another lockdown - will be 'enhanced contact tracing' as discussed with @didoharding in this week's select committee: backwards & forwards contact tracing combined with genomic sequencing of every +ve case.

It is clear that the biggest risk to our current strategy is the emergence of new variants that are immune or partially immune to the vaccine, a worst case scenario I asked @nadhimzahawi about today in parliament.

TB: ‘Treat social media companies as public interest companies. You can’t have a situation where the CEO of a company is deciding whether the President is allowed on social media.’
TB: ‘The only effective opposition to the SNP in the last decade was when @RuthDavidsonMSP was leader.’
JH: ‘You talked about the importance of holding the country together. Have things gone according to plan when it comes the devolution you introduced for Scotland?’
TB: ‘You’ve got to learn the right lessons...when you remove the dictatorship, other suppressed forces come to the surface.’
JH: ‘Do some of the challenges we face in the Western alliance relate to a loss of moral authority over military endeavours such as Iraq and Libya that have not turned out as expected?’
TB: ‘Other world leaders need to see you taking paint to make your alliance work...that’s when they’re with you.’
TB: ‘The absence of global co-operation over the pandemic ha been shocking.’

JH: You said real alliances are forged in adversity. Many think the Western alliance has broken down. What needs to happen to put it together & what is Britain’s role in making that happen? Robin Niblett of Chatham House argued that global Britain needs to be earned not declared.
TB: ‘The centre keeps people with us by carrying on making change...when it becomes the place of the status quo...you’re never going to win the debate. That’s what we lost.’

JH: Shortly before you became Labour leader Francis Fukuyama wrote ‘the End of History.’ With the benefit of hindsight - and seeing the terrible scenes on Capitol Hill just last week, have we been too complacent about the superiority of Western systems?
TB: ‘Of course you should be using data...we’ve got a massive opportunity with the NHS to use data in a constructive way and fuel innovation.’

TB: ‘Keep our universities - the centres of innovation - really strong. You need strong environment for enterprise, invest heavily in education and infrastructure. We have an advantage over China because enterprising people in China can only work within the confines of the state.

JH: ‘There is a big debate as to whether China will develop superior technology partly because looser rules on privacy could give it a big advantage in areas like AI. How important is it for the West to stay ahead on tech and what should be doing to make sure we do?’
TB: ‘The problem for democracy is it’s finding change and reform very difficult...that’s when populism comes along.’

TB: ‘The challenge of democracy is can you get stuff done....in the last election the debate on the NHS could have come from the 1980s. The real question is how do you use tech, pay attention to public health and get social care right.’

JH: The Centre for Economics and Business Research says that because of the pandemic, China will now overtake the US to become the world’s biggest economy in 2028. Elon Musk once said ‘the foundation of war is economics.’ Should those who believe in democratic values be worried?
...when it is only by rigorous analysis of the way the world is changing that we have any prospect of securing our future.’

TB: ‘The colossal downside risk for Britain is that the political debate continues in conventional directions – who spends or taxes more, who ‘supports’ most the NHS, who is most generous with welfare, umpteen versions of who preserves the status quo best...
TB: ‘The state of British politics makes me queasy!’
TB: ‘Our Armed Forces are globally admired. We should invest in them and make them at the cutting edge of military innovation in personnel, assets, and deployment.’
TB on aid.... ‘we still have a big budget, the merger, if properly used, could make more coherent our foreign policy offer, and make it weightier.’

TB: ‘The UK – with again some creativity – can help construct a bridge between these two positions, charting a path to ensuring at least some space for dialogue and cooperation with China, even as the West confronts and competes where necessary.’

TB: ‘Third, China is its own special issue. At present, Western countries are without a strategic framework for engagement, torn between seeming to appease a much more aggressive and powerful Chinese State and turning China into the 21st equivalent of the Soviet Union.’

TB: ‘We have huge relationships in the Gulf and Middle East; have developed a close relationship with Japan and South East Asia over time.
The point is we have a lot going for us; but we need to redouble the work to prove value.’

TB: ‘We need to recreate points of connection with our two key allies – Europe & USA. After Brexit, there is plenty we can do with Europe: climate change, pandemic preparedness; energy cooperation; aid...I could see us cooperating in areas like regulatory framework for big tech.’

TB: The aim should be to put us at the forefront of technological innovation and make Britain the best place in the world to do business. We will need major reforms to our public services, welfare, our regions and our infrastructure. Easy to say. Hard to do. Especially post Covid

TB: ‘People will pay more attention to us, treat our views more considerately, be more willing to be our allies, if our economy is strong, our society cohesive, if people look at us and see a nation to emulate.’

TB: ‘The right response therefore is to treat Brexit as a jolt, to act as a catalyst for change which is necessary even without Brexit and could have been done without doing Brexit, but which, by the challenge it poses, Brexit somehow enables.’
TB: ‘To succeed post Brexit, Britain must make radical changes. It is no longer: ‘Leave or Remain’ but ‘Change or Decline’.’ #CHevents

Tough measures announced tonight but thank you @BorisJohnson for doing what is necessary to save lives and get the virus under control

I know all these things will be under consideration with decisions potentially imminent. My point is in the face of exponential growth even waiting an extra day causes many avoidable deaths so these plans must now be urgently accelerated.

The good news is that unlike before these restrictions will be time limited to the 12 weeks or so it will take to get the vaccine out to those most vulnerable to covid - so there is light at the end of the tunnel.

Also with vacancy levels at 2-3 times normal because of self-isolation & covid, NHS staff who are risking their lives for us MUST be put at the front of the queue for vaccines. This will stop our hospitals falling over and help keep their patients safe. It is also our moral duty.

We therefore cannot afford to wait: all schools should be closed, international travel stopped, household mixing limited and the tier system reviewed so that the highest tier really does bring down infection levels (as with the first lockdown).

No 1 lesson is countries that act early & decisively save lives & get their economies back to normal faster. Wuhan is now free of any restrictions - but Uni of Southampton show if they’d locked down 1 week earlier they would’ve reduced infections by 2/3. https://t.co/1uWplUpIJA.

Excellent analysis by @NeilDotObrien shows the reason for all this pressure: 1/3 more hospital beds now taken up nationally by covid patients than in Wave 1 (50% in SE). Having a new strain in the middle of winter is clearly having a massive impact https://t.co/d3L3suUlxh

Full credit to NHS for keeping cancer services open but in Wave 1 there was still a 2/3 drop in cancer appts: people didn’t come forward to GPs or want to go to hospitals, with many potentially avoidable cancer deaths. We hoped to avoid that this time but now looking unlikely.

Even more worryingly fewer heart attack patients appear to be presenting in ICUs, perhaps because they are not dialling 999 when they need to
https://t.co/CM1548589N

It’s true that we often had to cancel elective care in Jan to protect emergency care but that too is under severe pressure with record trolley waits for the very sickest patients https://t.co/phEd47ztne
To those arguing winter is always like this in the NHS: you are wrong. I faced four serious winter crises as Health Sec and the situation now is off-the-scale worse than any of those.
Time to act: thread on why we need to close schools, borders, and ban all household mixing RIGHT AWAY.

Happy NY to all - horrible yr but 2 big silver linings: vaccines, where we may even be the first country to immunise all those at risk; & a Brexit deal which hopefully concludes a painful period in our politics. The future is now in our own hands - and never underestimate the UK!
PS thank you @WesselyS for offering to send me a Royal College of Pyschiatrists tie ahead of my next parliamentary intervention 😂

But it is extraordinary that NHS frontline staff are not EXPLICITLY at top of queue for the vaccine as in Germany: not only do we have a moral duty to keep them safe, they are also the people most capable of passing it on to vulnerable hospital patients. This needs to change

It is also sensible to change our vaccine policy to concentrate on getting as many first jabs done as possible - something made easier by the Oxford AZ vaccine which offers a longer window between first and second jabs.

It is right that some schools will remain closed next week & university starts are being delayed but it is still a big risk to open any schools at all with the virus exploding with the new strain and the NHS under severe pressure especially in parts of London.

This report MUST NOT be allowed to gather dust. Yes, Ministers are busy with Covid, but this sobering report must be a very high priority for Matt Hancock. I understand he is not delivering the statement today in parliament, understandable in a pandemic.
It is clear tht what went wrong forms a pattern with problems at Morecambe Bay, East Kent and potentially other trusts too on a scale that was unimaginable when I commissioned the review in 2017.

What is most shocking is the scale and longevity of this scandal: it poses many challenging questions for the NHS and its regulatory system as well as to the Trust. Many improvements have been made since the report was commissioned but more clearly needs to be done - and urgently

There are lessons that need to be learned immediately: no one should ever be pressurised to have a 'normal birth' in order to keep C-section rates low. The top priority must always be the safety of a child with any final decision taken by a mother on the basis of impartial advice

I am proud to have commissioned this report but sad that once again so much avoidable harm is cominmg to light. It’s time to banish that closed culture - and the blame culture that goes with it - so people can speak out and lessons can be learned more quickly when things go wrong

Finally, it’s truly sobering that here is yet ANOTHER report involving thousands of patients and families suffering avoidable harm, being ignored when they raise concerns and having to fight a closed and defensive system to get answers.
Not a quango but a person whose job is to give a powerful voice to patients and families who too often feel voiceless - and prevent avoidable harm and death happening to others.

A Patient Safety Commissioner is a smart idea because there is a gap: if your medicine or medical device has suspicious side effects who do you tell? Had such a role existed we could have avoided terrible agony for the patients interviewed for this report.

Other aspects of health have been too easily forgotten in the context of Covid. But this deserves our attention. As the report says, this is about ‘heart wrenching stories of acute suffering, families fractured and children harmed’. The recommendations should be implemented ASAP.

The high spread of infections in healthcare settings ('nosocomial' infections) has many lessons for patient safety: patients are safe when staff are safe which means PPE and regular testing. The sooner we get there the better.

On routine testing of staff they hid behind line 'we can only do what CMO recommends' but said we’d have capacity to test weekly by Sept/Oct. Still not convinced they see benefits of a structured programme to stop  asymptomatic transmission giving reassurance to patients & staff.

Also we looked at lessons learned re discharging people into care homes without testing, a major mistake early on in crisis. Reading between the lines I think this was recognised by Sir Simon & Steve Powis who agreed local NHS orgs should do all they can to support care homes.

But, major change coming to A & Es with 'call before you walk' 111-led system to avoid crowded A & Es. This would avoid risk of infections spreading but even post Covid means moving to Scandinavian system of bookable appointments for non-life threatening urgent & emergency care.

Also, for 1st time, we heard emergency admissions fell by 1/3 during pandemic. Of those only 1 in 14 were the most serious kind  but by my back of the envelope calculation around 40,000 people with serious non-Covid emergencies will not have got the hospital treatment they needed

However much more worrying that for elective care hospitals only running at 55% of capacity. This was backed up by NHS providers survey saying only 37% of acute trusts feel able to meet needs of all their patients. Long waits ahead for people who need new hips, knees, ankles etc.
Good news is that cancer treatment starts have remained at 96% of previous levels - although this won't necessarily reflect the drop in people coming forward because most cancer screening stopped.

My take on today's select committee hearing with Sir Simon Stevens, Amanda Pritchard & Prof Steve Powis: overall message is that despite rising brilliantly  to the Covid challenge it is going to be a BIG struggle to get back to normal.

With respect this is codswallop. Our challenges have had absolutely nothing to do with universal healthcare, indeed the response of NHS hospitals making sure we have had enough ventilators and ICU beds is arguably a demonstration of its strengths. https://t.co/1YhmjMzGP8

This morning's NAO report says up to 25,000 patients were discharged from hospitals to care homes without being tested.@ChrisCEOHopson right to say that some may have been tested - but given many weren't, extraordinary we did not appear to consider risks of asymptomatic infection

For strategy to work we urgently need to bridge that gap so everyone with symptoms ends up being investigated by NHS Test & Trace. Mass routine testing of those in care homes, hospitals & other public facing professions is only way I can see of doing this: https://t.co/uk4LMlUkW4

2nd concern is gap between no. picked up by Test & Trace (5,400 in 1st week so 800/day) & the 3-5000 people still likely to be infected across all settings each day. System is doing the right things but won’t be able to do its job if picking up > than 1/5 of new covid infections.

Fine to use postal tests for routine testing in care homes etc but with a potential spreader we must find out fast. In fairness this seems to be the plan: https://t.co/sQwtcxBFbu but no commitment to publish proportion of Test & Trace tests returned within the vital 24 hr period.

This does not bode well. To be clear what matters is NOT whether the target is met (postal votes are around one third of all tests so when you exclude them the target is pretty meaningless). It is whether ALL the tests NHS test and trace needs are done within 24 hours.

But 2 concerns: v. worrying there is STILL no data on no of tests completed in 24 hrs. PM target is to complete all except postal tests within 24 hours by end of June (less than 3 weeks). But despite many requests Gov says data still not reliable enough to publish this number.
Given how new the system is I think getting these kind of results is an impressive performance by Dido Harding and her team - and I am sure the numbers will continue to improve.

But 85% of 67% of 79%…is just 45% of close contacts of those with covid being asked to isolate within 48 hours of a positive test. But the real no will be higher as many close contacts live within the same household & they’re already asked to isolate when someone tests positive.

On the face of it these are encouraging no.s. A high proportion of people with positive tests being contacted within 24 hrs (79%) of which 2/3 are successfully sharing the names of close contacts. Of those 85% are being asked to isolate within 24 hrs with vast majority complying.

In Germany they’re recruiting 5 contact tracers for every 20,000 people. In Singapore they deploy the army. In Korea they involve every part of national and local government. All use hybrid combinations of feet on the street, phoning and tech to stop the virus in its tracks.

The logistical challenge shouldn’t be underestimated; this is bigger than building the Nightingales or PPE distribution. But the definition of success is simple: can anyone with symptoms get a test in 24 hours? And can we trace 80-90% of their contacts in the following 24 hours?

But we need to see more detail: will it be centrally co-ordinated by PHE or led locally by councils? Will we have a senior leader to manage the programme given PHE and DH leadership are already working round the clock? What will the balance be between tech & traditional methods?

No one can reasonably expect governments to have a crystal ball with a brand new virus, so full credit to the government for being willing to learn from international best practice, first on ramping up testing and now on mass contact tracing.

Final caveat: these numbers are constantly changing with new information. But from the outside this is what currently feels most likely.

Most importantly, we can learn how to flatten the peak and give the NHS the best possible chance of saving more lives. But there will also be political as opposed to scientific judgements: the right balance between slowing the virus and reducing economic disruption.

Of course the right actions taken decisively could reduce those numbers significantly: we know more about the virus because of what has happened in China, Italy, Iran, South Korea and other countries. In particular we know about the risks to older people and how to reduce them.

Chris Whitty was much more certain about mortality rates being around 1%. So 10% of the population means around four times the annual average deaths for seasonal flu, but only slightly higher than when it peaked at just over 50,000 flu deaths in the winter of 2017-18.
Of course other parts of China including Beijing and Shanghai have fared much better than Hubei province and Wuhan, so we can also hope to do better than that in the UK.

He also cautioned China could see a 2nd or even 3rd wave, possibly when some of the current extreme measures were relaxed. So overall he thinks it unlikely we could keep the numbers as low as 5% of UK population, but reasonable to hope it will end up being less than 20%.

Chris Whitty used a figure of 20% of population in Wuhan province when he came in front of the select committee, but says those with symptoms are likely to be 5% or less. WHO figures are lower - only 0.1% of population - but there is likely to be significant under-reporting.

Yesterday was the first day confirmed new cases in the UK exceeded those in China (67 in the UK vs 40 in China). Last week Chris Whitty told the select committee he saw ‘no reason in theory why the UK would go higher than China.’ So how bad did it get in China?
As soon as the government officially moves us to the ‘delay’ stage, it is effectively confirming that an epidemic IS coming. So on the basis of the information we currently have, what's the outlook?

Has the NHS got safer? Since the introduction of Ofsted-style ratings by the CQC there is much more transparency about poor care at an institutional level. 40 NHS trusts have been put into special measures (around a fifth) of which half have exited and 6 now have a good rating.

Nor should private providers get away with worse clinical governance than NHS trusts, especially when under contract to the NHS. Shocking that some of the Spire patients STILL don’t have a care plan. This makes me worry private sector care may currently be less safe than NHS care

Sorting out our Brexit paralysis matters, but being able to promise families who have suffered unimaginable heartache ‘never again’ matters much more.
Our best hospitals have this but in other places a blame culture still means fear of litigation, castigation or losing your job makes it difficult for staff to be open about mistakes.
But for me the single most important thing is to nurture a proper learning culture, where the first objective when something goes wrong is to learn the lessons and make sure it is never repeated.

Staffing levels matter and it will take time for the increases in doctor, nurse and midwife training places to feed through into more staff on the ground. Until then NHS staff will continue to deliver extraordinarily compassionate care under enormous pressure.

We also have a national programme to halve stillbirths, neonatal & maternal deaths by 2025. Taken together this probably makes the NHS a world leader in maternity safety - which we need to be because, tragically, we still have four neonatal deaths EVERY SINGLE DAY in England.

Lots has changed: we have a tough independent CQC inspection regime, a new national body dedicated to learning lessons from these incidents (HSIB), independent investigations of every serious incident and a ‘duty of candour’ when things go wrong.
But the sheer scale and duration of this scandal should prompt some serious soul-searching which I hope doesn’t get lost in election coverage.

A Prime Minister willing to walk away. But a Prime Minister who will give negotiations a chance, and put in place a proper strategy to ensure they succeed. #HastobeHunt

Without the right Prime Minister and the right plan, Brexit is just a wing and a prayer. We can do better. Britain needs a Prime Minister for all weathers. One who will work tirelessly to get a deal but will also put in the hard yards preparing for no deal. #HastobeHunt

In the end I have always said that Britain will flourish regardless of the way we left the European Union. But we need to be realistic about the short term impact and I am prepared to step in and help smooth those difficulties. #HastobeHunt

We spent just over £1 trillion bailing out the banks after the financial crisis. So if we did it for the bankers then why wouldn’t we do it what is needed for our fishermen and our farmers now? #HastobeHunt

While we are committed to open trade, we will not be naïve or careless of the legitimate defence of our industries, including those which have played such a crucial role in our nation’s story.  We will develop support funds to provide direct assistance to those most in need.

And the chances of no deal, far from being a million to one, are real which is why we must prepare. The point about making no deal a credible threat is that you actually have to prepare for it. #HastobeHunt

So I urge any colleagues thinking of blocking no deal to reflect that you may in fact be making it harder to get a negotiated exit, by giving the EU misplaced confidence that we will give ground, and ultimately increasing the chance that we leave without one. #HastobeHunt

In any negotiation you need leverage, and part of ours is showing that we have a plan to ensure we succeed as a country through a no deal Exit from the EU, and we are willing to use it if an acceptable deal can’t be done. #HastobeHunt

No deal is obviously not my preferred destination. But if a withdrawal deal is simply not on the cards then the only way to fulfil the democratic mandate of the referendum is to leave without a deal which is what we will do. #HastobeHunt
So from the start of my Premiership, I will work on the basis we are leaving on 31st October without a deal unless the Commission changes its position. #HastobeHunt

But I want to be crystal clear: if there is no engagement on this deal, if it is apparent that the Commission is simply not interested in negotiating, then there will be no kicking the can down the road and we will intensify and finalise our preparations to leave without a deal.

If we are close to getting a deal and it will take a few more weeks, then so be it. With a deal done, billions will be available to invest in the economic and social mission I have set out. #HastobeHunt
If negotiations are going well, then I do not believe we should ignore the progress made, throw away that deal and stick to the 31st October as a deadline to leave, come what may. #HastobeHunt

One thing I will not negotiate on is citizens’ rights. So to put the millions of EU citizens who have made the UK their home at ease, I can reconfirm to them that their rights in the UK are protected. #HastobeHunt

10. (2) If my judgement is that there is no deal to be done I will immediately cease all discussions with the European Union and focus the whole country’s attention on no deal preparations. #HastobeHunt

10. Following the vote for the new plan in the House of Commons I will then allow 3 weeks for negotiations with the EU. As PM I will make a judgement on 30th Sept as to whether there is a realistic chance of a new deal being agreed that can pass the House of Commons. #HastobeHunt
9. I will provide the necessary finance to support the development of customs solutions which can help deliver our cast iron guarantee that we will never put up a hard border. #HastobeHunt

8. We will pursue the government’s existing approach to tariffs, balancing the benefits of liberalisation for consumers with appropriate exceptions to safeguard vulnerable industries and protect the prosperity and wellbeing of communities across every part of the UK. #HastobeHunt

7. HMT will also produce a ‘No Deal Relief Programme’. This includes a £6bn fund for the fishing and farming sectors who export to Europe to ease transition out of the European Union whilst honouring our international obligations. #HastobeHunt

6. The Treasury will start preparations on a No Deal Brexit Budget to be delivered in the 1st week parliament is back in Sept. This will include cutting corporation tax cut to 12.5%, increasing the annual allowance to £5m, and taking 90% of high street businesses out of rates.
5. I will also establish a National Logistics Committee led by the Department for Transport to produce a plan to keep goods flowing in and out of the UK in the event of No Deal. #HastobeHunt
4. In order to avoid a ‘take it or leave it’ approach I and the Brexit Secretary will engage with European leaders and the European Commission during July and August. #HastobeHunt

3. A new political negotiating team with members of the ERG, DUP, One Nation Group & Welsh & Scottish Conservatives, led by the Brexit Secretary and supported at an official level by Crawford Falconer. He will be supported by top experts from around the world. #HastobeHunt

2. A ‘No Deal’ Cabinet Task Force: to follow up any areas where government preparations are insufficient, to agree & publish financial support for industries affected by tariff changes & to approve infrastructure changes that may not be completed by 31st Oct #HastobeHunt

1.On day one of my Premiership I would order an immediate ramping up of No Deal preparations. All government departments will be expected to act on the basis that we are leaving without a deal on October 31st #HastobeHunt
Today I am setting out my 10 point plan. #HastobeHunt
But belief alone won’t cut it. Rhetoric is not enough. This is about the hard graft, focus and attention to detail. Deal or no deal. #HastobeHunt

But before we can make any of those changes we must do one thing above all else. We must leave the European Union. And we must do so quickly.
 
Uncertainty is bad for business. Bad for politics. And bad for our country. #HastobeHunt

Choose me and I will take us through this time of crisis, deliver Brexit, and get us back to walking tall in the world.
So choose me for unity over division. For experience over rhetoric. For tough negotiation over empty threats.

A country saved by the heroes of D-day we remembered last week, that looks to the future with as much confidence as the pride with which it remembers its past. That is the potential I seek to unleash. That is the country I seek to lead.

The biggest single reason that I want to be Prime Minister is to make sure my children and grandchildren enjoy the same opportunities I did. To grow up in a prosperous and free country, bursting with opportunity for every single one of its citizens.
I want young people everywhere to know that a Conservative government is there for you. So yesterday I published five pledges for young people. https://t.co/T6nktefMwl
Most of all, though, I want Conservatives to get our mojo back politically. How can the party of aspiration turn its backs on our most aspirational people?
So I pledge to increase the percentage of our GDP we spend on defence alongside maintaining our commitment to 0.7% on international development.
Then this country needs to get its confidence back and start walking tall in the world. We need properly funded armed forces.
So I will negotiate a long-term plan with the teaching profession: more funding in return for a guarantee that we will be the first generation to abolish illiteracy
It means a social mission. Prosperity not just for its own sake but prosperity with a purpose. I want our next social mission to be education.

That means an economic vision. As a tech entrepreneur, I will fire up our country to be the world’s next Silicon Valley, a hub of innovation based on our world-class universities, our creativity and our inventiveness.
But just as I have never defined my own politics by Brexit, nor must we as a party. We need to broaden our appeal to remainers, to women, to minorities, to young people and to the centre ground.

So faced with bad choices, we need a Prime Minister who can negotiate some better choices. Having talked to many European leaders, I believe if we show determination, ingenuity and confidence, there is a deal to be done.
The lessons of the European and Peterborough elections are clear. If we fight an election before delivering Brexit, we will be annihilated.
With me to face the unyielding Brussels machine, you’ll be sending in a Prime Minister who has been negotiating all his life.
So as a campaigner, I know challenging elections can be won. As an entrepreneur, I know there’s no success without risk. And as a Brit, I know there’s nothing our great country can’t achieve.

I would be the first Prime Minister for half a century who has won a marginal seat. Like Amber Rudd, whose endorsement I was proud to receive yesterday, I know what it’s like to fight for every single vote.
The person most likely to do that is someone who can negotiate a deal that will pass through parliament.

Whoever delivers Brexit will win the next election for the Conservative party.  But without Brexit no Conservative Prime Minister can win. So delivering Brexit and winning the next election are not different things - they are the same.

Our failure to deliver Brexit has put our country and our party in grave peril. The leadership I offer is based on one simple truth: without Brexit there will be no Conservative government and maybe no Conservative Party.
